data.title: A touch of my childhood
data.text: German deli, bakery, and German food store. Some of these things and brands are hard to find here in the US. I ate my pretzel on the drive home! It was much lighter than expected and quite large (and I got the small one). At least a dozen types of salami. If you want authentic German foods this is your stop. What an unexpected pleasant surprise !

data.title: Go there for a treat
data.text: The pastries are made fresh daily and delicious.  I wouldn't want to go every day, but this place is a nice treat to satisfy your sweet tooth.

data.title: german bakery
data.text: Bought a couple of snacks from here. seemed clean.Help was very nice, Thought the selection would of been more variety...

data.title: A German themed cafe and pastry shop with not so good products
data.text:
German Pastry & Coffee Shop is located in a building that also houses a German bakery and delicatessen. The selection of the pastries, cakes and pies is good, but that also brings up the biggest negative about this place. I have been to the German Pastry & Coffee Shop numerous times and in most cases you are sold old pastries, half frozen pastries and stale cakes. It seems that the phrase "fresh" is foreign to the proprietor of this place. Another really odd thing is that you will be charged a penalty if you buy a whole cake, unless you ordered it a week ahead.
Needless to say, they have lost my business.

data.title: YUM!
data.text:
Had coffee and a roll.  Very good Meeting place for regulars.
The waitress was right there with refills.  On the other side of the entrance was a German Deli and grocery store.  Looked really interesting.

data.title: Superb!
data.text: This place is excellent.  It is often confused with the Hess Bakery and Deli.  While separate, I always believe they are the same place.  This is our go-to place for breakfast and lunch when we are unsure of where to go.  Did I mention we love it?!

data.title: Always a treat to visit and bring home a bag of goodies
data.text:
We stopped in on a rainy Saturday and had to wait for a parking spot. This place is popping!

Love to walk the aisles and read the labels of all the fun German food. They have a great candy selection and lots of black licorice choices and that makes me happy. The meats and cheese deli counter is all sliced while you wait. We love the bread counter and always bring home the pretzels and sweet/hot mustard they sell in little cups.

data.title: Love this spot for fattening fixes
data.text:
This has been one of my favorite sweet spots for many years and the different owners. Bee stings and almond cookie bars are either sold out or a rare occasion so I try to get in early to grab the goodies because they do sell fast. However, the cakes tend to dry out too fast if not baked fresh within hours of consumption. Some of our family favorites are the chocolate whipped cream, chocolate buttercream, cheesecake (which is delightfully cakey not so creamy) and marzipan. The whole cakes average $38, which is a great price compared to corporate store-bought cakes (which tend to taste as such). 

If one chooses to consume coffee and pastries (or even German sandwiches) on the premises, there are extra charges, as stated on the menu board. 

They also sell gift certificates and the parking lot is shared with Hess Deli but is always crowded.

data.title: My Favorite German Deli in Lakewood
data.text: I stop in this deli for lunch at least once per month and have never been disappointed.  The staff is always friendly, but it it the food that keeps me coming back over and over again.  The breads are always fresh and the sandwiches made to order.  The pastries?  They are fantastic!  Love this place!

data.title: Pastries better than those in Bavaria!
data.text:
These are the best German pastries to be had in the South Sound. Many of their specialties (coffee cake, cookies) are better than what's available at most Bavarian bakeries. The coffee cake is amazing! And next door Hess German Bakery and Deli/Market is a great place to get authentic pretzels and German convenience foods like Knödel mix.  

The decor hasn't been touched since the 1980s, and it's not the place to go for broccoli soup, but the pastries are fantastic for take-out.

data.title: Authentic German Food; Excellent Pastries
data.text: This place has been in business for at least 30 years. It is in the same brick office building as the awesome Hess German Bakery and Deli/Market, although the two businesses are not connected. While this is not the best German/European restaurant in the area (That honor goes to Bruno's European Cafe in Parkland), the food here is well-prepared and authentic. Best feature is the selection of German pastries, which are as good as you'd find in Heidelberg or Berlin!
